annotations.description: Protocol describes a method for generating spinal neural rosette (SNR)-derived brain organoids with predictable organization and reproducible cellular composition, mimicking natural neural tube development. Key modifications include: (1) use of vitamin A-containing B27 supplement, (2) no Wnt inhibitors, (3) prolonged early treatment with FGF2 and EGF, and (4) late transient exposure to trophic factors.

Compared to other protocols, this method uses FGF2 and EGF treatment and MG embedding to promote neural progenitor proliferation, resulting in larger organoids (>1.2 mm diameter by 5 months) with consistent organization and improved functional maturation.

1-month-old SNR-derived organoids contain telencephalic neural progenitors and inhibitory and excitatory neurons, enabling study of neural lineage specification via scRNA-seq-based computational lineage tracing.

5-month-old organoids contain diverse neural cells: excitatory and inhibitory progenitors, deep and superficial layer cortical excitatory neurons, LGE-derived inhibitory interneurons, primary striatal inhibitory neurons, astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, periendothelial and ependymal cells. Ependymal cells line the lumen; cortical neurons exhibit lamination; striatal neurons are distributed beneath cortical layers.

5-month-old organoids contain functionally mature neurons that generate action potentials, receive excitatory and inhibitory synaptic inputs, and demonstrate functional neural networks, suitable for studying neural network development in the human brain.

The SNR-based approach can be adapted to generate other brain region-specific organoids (striatal, thalamic, cerebellar, midbrain) for assembling multi-region organoids to study inter-regional communication, migration, and connectivity.
Organoids with predictable organization and reproducible cellular composition may be useful for building biocomputers for artificial intelligence applications.
Limitations include manual procedures for SNR isolation and heterogeneity in isolated SNRs (size, shape, quality), contributing to organoid-to-organoid variability.
